Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Expectation2: Complete any assignments or tasks given by the mentor.
Situation2: The mentor assigned a code sample to be finished before the next meeting in three days.
Story:
I stared at my laptop, the code sample from my mentor blinking back at me, half-finished and riddled with errors. The deadline was tight—just three days—and I knew how much my mentor valued diligence and follow-through. Every time I’d met with her, she’d emphasized the importance of meeting deadlines and showing initiative. I wanted to prove myself, to show her I was serious about this opportunity.

My phone buzzed, and I glanced at the screen. It was Sunday evening—time for my weekly call with my parents. I could already imagine my mom’s gentle voice, asking about my week, and my dad’s quiet questions about whether I was eating well. They looked forward to these calls, and so did I, usually. It was our way of staying close, even though I lived hours away. I knew they’d worry if I skipped it, maybe even feel hurt.

But the code wasn’t going to write itself, and every minute spent on the phone was a minute lost. My chest tightened as I weighed the expectations: a devoted daughter, a committed mentee. I stared at my phone, torn, the cursor blinking accusingly on the screen.
